    Your outside offer value is 241. 

    The negotiation proceeds in 3 rounds.
    There is a discount rate gamma = 0.9, such that if the process concludes after r rounds the overall value of the negotiation to each player is their value for the outcome multiplied by gamma to the power (r-1).
    At each round, Player 1 takes an action, followed by Player 2.
    The possible actions are to ACCEPT the other player's current offer (if any), make a COUNTEROFFER, or WALK away.  If the game gets to the last round, and player 2 chooses to make a counteroffer, this is treated as a WALK.
    If a player chooses ACCEPT, the negotiation ends in a deal to divide the items according to the accepted offer.
    The value of an outcome is determined by each player's private values per unit of each item and the quantities they receive in the deal. This value is adjusted by the discount factor, which is used to compute the present value of the negotiation outcome.
    If a player chooses WALK, the negotiation ends without a deal, and each player receives the value of their private outside offer.

round_data.response:
My current offer gives me [0, 4, 6, 3, 2] units, meaning I’d “receive” these units outright. With my private per‐unit values, that works out to:
• Item 1: 0 × 24 = 0
• Item 2: 4 × 22 = 88
• Item 3: 6 × 54 = 324
• Item 4: 3 × 12 = 36
• Item 5: 2 × 45 = 90
Total = 538

Because this is round 1 the discount factor is 1 (gamma^(0)=1), so I get 538 in present value. My private outside offer is only 4, so the alternative is very unattractive.

While I might be able to try to “improve” my share by proposing a counteroffer, doing so risks delaying an agreement into later rounds where the discounting (0.9 in round 2, etc.) would reduce the present value considerably. Moreover, without knowing Player 1’s values, a counteroffer that tries to extract more on my side might not be acceptable to them. Given that 538 is a high immediate payoff compared to my outside option, it is optimal for me to secure this deal now.

Thus, I choose to ACCEPT the current offer.

{"action": "ACCEPT"}

round_data.response:
My items’ total value (588) is barely higher than my outside offer (584). In the current offer I’d be getting [0, 3, 1, 2, 2] which gives me a value of 366—well below my outside option. In round 1 I can counteroffer so that, if accepted, I’d obtain nearly all items. However, to beat my outside offer I would have to retain at least 584 in value out of 588. That leaves me only a margin of 4 points to “pay” for any concession to Player 1. Given my private per‐unit values (7, 32, 8, 67, 64), even giving up a single unit of the least valuable item (item 1 worth 7 to me) would drop my value to 581—below my outside offer. In other words, any counteroffer that gives Player 1 any items makes my share worth less than my outside option. Thus, I cannot offer a division that both improves Player 1’s incentives to accept and maintains my value above or equal to 584. Since the current offer gives me only 366, my best course is to walk away and claim my outside option.

{"action": "WALK"}

round_data.response:
I'll explain my thought process before giving my final action.

We note that there are 5 items available in quantities [2, 4, 5, 4, 6] and our private per‐unit values are [18, 19, 16, 19, 26]. (Thus our total full value would be 424.) Our outside option guarantees us 71, so any deal we accept should give us more than that. Because we are the first proposer (round 1, with no discount yet), we want to propose a division that gives us as high a share as possible while offering the other side just enough to get an offer they would accept instead of relying on their outside option. Even though we don’t know Player 2’s exact values, their per‐unit values are uniformly drawn from 1 to 101 so the averages are around 51 per unit. In designing our offer we want to use items that are less important to us (those with lower private value) to “bribe” Player 2. For us, item 3 is the lowest (16 per unit) and item 1 (18 per unit) is next lowest compared to our other items. In contrast, we particularly value items like item 5 (26 each) and also value significant parts of item 2 and 4 (each 19)—so we’d like to keep most of them.

A plausible strategy is to offer Player 2 only a minimal share that would give them an expected value not far below the average outside offer (which we know is 71 for us, though their actual outside offer is unknown, it’s reasonable to assume they’d require an offer above that). By offering them 1 unit of item 1 and 1 unit of item 3 (i.e. a counteroffer of [1, 0, 1, 0, 0]), Player 2 would receive 1 unit of item 1 and 1 unit of item 3. The expected value of these two units (with average ~51 per unit) would be around 102 in expectation—comfortably above 71 on average. Meanwhile, we get the remainder: [1, 4, 4, 4, 6] which gives us a utility of 1*18 + 4*19 + 4*16 + 4*19 + 6*26 = 18 + 76 + 64 + 76 + 156 = 390, a strong result. 

Thus, my final decision is to propose the counteroffer: 
{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 0, 1, 0, 0]}.

round_data.response:
I want to get nearly all of the items that are most valuable to me and “pay” the least possible “price” by conceding the items I value very little. My private values show that item 4 is worth only 3 per unit; by comparison, the other items are worth 40 or more. (In fact, my goods’ total value adds up to 700 if I got everything, but my outside option is only 282.) In a first‐round offer the proposer can be very aggressive because any delay (and switching roles) will incur a discount (γ = 0.9 per round). Although I don’t know Player 2’s exact private values, on average their value per unit is around 51 (by the uniform draw on 1 to 101), so I expect that giving them all 11 units of item 4 will be attractive compared to their outside alternative. I'll analyze the situation as follows.

Currently Player 1’s offer would give me: 0 of item1, 1 of item2, 0 of item3, 0 of item4, 0 of item5. With my values (85, 49, 37, 9, 98), that makes 0·85 + 1·49 + 0 + 0 + 0 = 49 – far below both what I could get if I won all items (total value 1417) and even below my outside offer of 755.

So I need to propose a counteroffer that leaves me with at least more than 755 in my payoff when I get my share. Note that if I propose an offer where I give Player 1 a bundle (x1, x2, x3, x4, x5) then I would keep the remainder: [9 – x1, 4 – x2, 1 – x3, 3 – x4, 4 – x5]. My total value would be

  1417 – (85·x1 + 49·x2 + 37·x3 + 9·x4 + 98·x5).

To secure more than 755 for myself I need to keep at least 756 value for myself. At the same time I want the offer to be appealing enough to Player 1 for them to accept rather than play on (especially since future rounds discount the total value).

One natural approach is to try to keep most of the items that I value very highly (item1 and item5; worth 85 and 98 per unit) and offer some share of those “good” items to Player 1 along with all of the items I value less (items 2, 3, and 4). For example, if I were to simply take all of item1 and item5 then I’d get 9·85 + 4·98 = 765 + 392 = 1157 – which is clearly above my outside offer – but Player 1 would get only items I consider low value. To increase the likelihood they find the deal attractive, I can offer them a slice of item1 as well.

A balanced proposal is to give Player 1:
 • 3 units of item 1,
 • all of item 2 (4 units),
 • the single unit of item 3,
 • all of item 4 (3 units), and
 • 1 unit of item 5.
That means my counteroffer to Player 1 would be [3, 4, 1, 3, 1]. Then I would receive the remainder:
 • item 1: 9 – 3 = 6 units,
 • item 2: 4 – 4 = 0,
 • item 3: 1 – 1 = 0,
 • item 4: 3 – 3 = 0,
 • item 5: 4 – 1 = 3.
My total value would then be 6·85 + 3·98 = 510 + 294 = 804, which is comfortably above my outside offer of 755. In my measure, Player 1 gets “worth” 3·85 + 4·49 + 1·37 + 3·9 + 1·98 = 255 + 196 + 37 + 27 + 98 = 613—providing them with a decent share of the items and hopefully an incentive to agree rather than walking away for an uncertain outside offer.

Based on this reasoning, I will make the following counteroffer:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [3, 4, 1, 3, 1]}

round_data.response:
My analysis begins by comparing the value you’d get if you accepted the current offer. Accepting [3, 2, 0, 2, 3] would grant you:
 • Item 1: 3 units × 72 = 216
 • Item 2: 2 units × 94 = 188
 • Item 3: 0 units × 64 = 0
 • Item 4: 2 units × 6 = 12
 • Item 5: 3 units × 92 = 276
  Total = 216 + 188 + 0 + 12 + 276 = 692

Because this is round 1 (discount factor 1.0) and your outside offer is 264, 692 is much better; however, you can improve your position by making a counteroffer.

You know your own values and note that you have a strong advantage on items 1, 2, 3, and 5 relative to a typical (average) opponent (whose values are around 51 on average). In contrast, you value item 4 very little (6 per unit), so you are happy to concede all of it. The current division (from Player 1’s offer) gives Player 1 the complementary bundle:
 • Item 1: 3 units (since total is 6)
 • Item 2: 4 units (total 6)
 • Item 3: 4 units (total 4)
 • Item 4: 3 units (total 5)
 • Item 5: 3 units (total 6)
This yields about 17 units. In expected terms (using a rough average of 51 per unit) that’s around 867 “points” for them.

Your goal is to improve your own score while leaving the opponent with roughly the same overall “size” of bundle, just shifting the mix to give them more of the low‐value (to you) item 4 and less of the high‐value ones. One natural idea is to “squeeze” a bit by offering them fewer units of items 1, 2, and 5 (which you value highly) and compensate by giving them more units of item 4 (which you value very little). For example, if you offer them:
 Item 1: 2 units (down from 3)
 Item 2: 3 units (down from 4)
 Item 3: 4 units (keeping it as is)
 Item 4: 5 units (raising from 3 – and all of it, since total is 5)
 Item 5: 3 units (same)
then their bundle would be [2, 3, 4, 5, 3]. (This is feasible because the totals per item remain within the max available: 2 ≤6, 3 ≤6, 4 =4, 5 =5, 3 ≤6.) Under this counteroffer your share becomes the remaining units:
 Item 1: 6–2 = 4
 Item 2: 6–3 = 3
 Item 3: 4–4 = 0
 Item 4: 5–5 = 0
 Item 5: 6–3 = 3
Your resulting utility is:
 Item 1: 4×72 = 288
 Item 2: 3×94 = 282
 Item 3: 0×64 = 0
 Item 4: 0×6 = 0
 Item 5: 3×92 = 276
  Total = 288 + 282 + 276 = 846, which is a substantial improvement over 692.

For Player 1 the offered bundle is rearranged from the current split. In a simplified analysis (using an average value of about 51 per unit), the total number of units they would get is still 2+3+4+5+3 = 17, very similar to the current split. (In items where you reduce their share, you “make up” by handing over extra of item 4 that they might value more than you do.) Thus, the counteroffer is designed to be just as attractive to them while boosting your own outcome.

Based on this, my chosen action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [2, 3, 4, 5, 3]}

round_data.response:
My current offer gives me only 2 units of item 5, which at my value of 26 per unit equals 52. Discounted (0.9 factor since we are in round 2) that is 46.8 in present value—far inferior to my guaranteed outside offer of 461. Since any counteroffer in round 2 would push the negotiation into the final round (further discounting any potential deal) and carries the risk that Player 1 might not accept it, my best outcome is achieved by walking away and obtaining my outside offer value.

{"action": "WALK"}

round_data.response:
I want to propose an offer that gives me a high‐value share while conceding enough “low‐value” goods to make it attractive for Player 2 to accept rather than risk delaying and ending up with their outside offer. My private values are very high on item 1 (76 per unit) and very low on item 5 (6 per unit), with moderate values on items 2, 3, and 4. I therefore try to keep all of item 1 entirely for myself and offer, when possible, the items I value less (or that I have in excess) to Player 2. One possible split is as follows:

• Offer Player 2 nothing of item 1 (all 3 units remain with me).  
• Give 4 units of item 2 (out of 6 units) to Player 2 so that I keep 2 units (valuing these at 2×15 = 30).  
• Give 4 units of item 3 (out of 9) to Player 2 so that I keep 5 units (valuing these at 5×47 = 235).  
• Since there is only 1 unit of item 4, I give it to Player 2 (valuing 40 each) so that I keep none.  
• I give all 3 units of item 5 (worth 6 each) to Player 2 so that I keep none.

Then my resulting bundle is:  
• Item 1: 3 units → 3×76 = 228  
• Item 2: 2 units → 2×15 = 30  
• Item 3: 5 units → 5×47 = 235  
• Item 4: 0 units → 0  
• Item 5: 0 units → 0  
Total value for me = 228 + 30 + 235 = 493, which exceeds my outside offer of 431 in round 1.

Based on these considerations, I now make the following offer providing Player 2 with the quantities [0, 4, 4, 1, 3]:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 4, 4, 1, 3]}

round_data.response:
Step‐by‐step reasoning:
1. We have 5 item types with totals [4, 6, 2, 2, 4] and my private per‐unit values [45, 59, 93, 52, 67]. My total value for all items is 1092. My external fallback (outside offer) is worth 494.
2. Since it is round 1 (with no offer on the table) and the discount factor is 0.9 per extra round, we want to secure an agreement early that nets me better than the 494 fallback.
3. I also know that my highest‐value items are items 3 and 5 (with values 93 and 67 respectively) so I wish to retain most of them. Meanwhile, I can be more flexible on items for which my own value is relatively lower (e.g. items 1, 2, and 4) so that I offer Player 2 enough value so that they prefer a deal now rather than risk a discounted outcome later.
4. An initial offer that does this is to propose splitting the “low‐value” items almost evenly (for example, offering half the total of items 1, 2 and 4 to Player 2) while keeping most of the “high‐value” items (items 3 and most of item 5) for myself.
5. One such offer is: offer Player 2 2 units of item 1 (out of 4), 3 of item 2 (out of 6), none of item 3 (keeping both units), 1 of item 4 (out of 2), and 1 of item 5 (out of 4). Under this division I keep:
  • Item 1: 4 – 2 = 2 units (2×45 = 90)
  • Item 2: 6 – 3 = 3 units (3×59 = 177)
  • Item 3: 2 – 0 = 2 units (2×93 = 186)
  • Item 4: 2 – 1 = 1 unit (1×52 = 52)
  • Item 5: 4 – 1 = 3 units (3×67 = 201)
  Totaling 90+177+186+52+201 = 706,
which is well above my fallback 494. Meanwhile, Player 2’s allocation (the offer) gives them some “winning” share on several items.
6. This distribution seems a reasonable initial offer, balancing my interest (keeping high‐value items) with leaving enough value to Player 2 so that they might accept (or at least not immediately walk away).

Thus, my action is to make this counteroffer.

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [2, 3, 0, 1, 1]}

round_data.response:
My reasoning:
My private values make the current offer very attractive. Accepting the current offer would give me:
• 1 unit of item 1 valued at 40,
• 1 unit of item 2 valued at 31, and
• 1 unit of item 5 valued at 67.
This totals 138, which is far above my outside offer of 18, and we are still in round 1 (no discount yet). Since I also highly value item 4 (91) and it isn’t included in the offer, I might be tempted to counter for more of that item. However, countering risks a breakdown in negotiations (especially with the potential discount in later rounds) without knowing Player 1’s private values. Aiming for a higher share might jeopardize a sure high payoff (138) compared to what I might end up with if the negotiation prolongs.
Thus, it seems optimal to accept the current offer.

{"action": "ACCEPT"}

round_data.response:
My reasoning:
• Currently, Player 1’s offer gives me [2, 0, 0, 0, 1] which, at my private per‐unit values (77, 77, 64, 67, 43), is worth 2×77 + 1×43 = 154 + 43 = 197. This is much lower than my outside offer of 1096.
• Since I must at least match my outside option (after discount, here no discount since it’s round 1), I need a deal that leaves me with at least 1096 in value.
• My maximum attainable value (if I got everything) would be 1454. Thus, the maximum concession I can offer to Player 1 (in terms of my own values) is 1454 – 1096 = 358.
• To minimize the concession (and maximize my gain) I want to allocate items to Player 1 that have low value to me. Among the items, item 5 is the lowest valued (43 per unit). By offering Player 1 all 6 units of item 5, the concession in my valuation is 6×43 = 258, which is less than 358.
• In that case, my remaining share will be everything else: [5, 8, 2, 1, 0], for a value of 5×77 + 8×77 + 2×64 + 1×67 = 385 + 616 + 128 + 67 = 1196, safely above my outside offer.
• Thus, I propose the counteroffer that gives Player 1 all of item 5 and I keep the others.

round_data.response:
My reasoning:
• If we accept the current offer [1, 3, 2, 0, 1], we would receive 1 unit of item1, 3 of item2, 2 of item3, 0 of item4, and 1 of item5. With our values (11, 17, 90, 16, 39) this gives a raw total of 1×11 + 3×17 + 2×90 + 0×16 + 1×39 = 11 + 51 + 180 + 0 + 39 = 281. Because we are in round 2 the deal is discounted by 0.9, so its present‐value becomes 281×0.9 = 252.9. This is below our outside offer of 283, so accepting is unattractive.

• In earlier rounds we had proposed [2, 3, 2, 0, 1] (which would have given us the complement [2, 2, 4, 1, 0]). That deal, had it been accepted, would have netted us 2×11 + 2×17 + 4×90 + 1×16 + 0×39 = 22 + 34 + 360 + 16 = 432 raw points—far above our reservation. However, Player 2 did not go with that proposal.

• In round 2 we want our deal (when discounted by 0.9) to be at least as good as walking away for 283. That requires our raw valuation to be at least about 283/0.9 ≈ 314, and ideally somewhat higher.

• One way to “buy” the acceptance of Player 2 is to offer them a division that gives up enough value so that our share is close to (but above) our minimum acceptable raw value. In our view, the total value available is 724. If we target a raw value for ourselves of about 320 (because 320×0.9 = 288, slightly above our outside offer of 283), then we must “give” to Player 2 a bundle worth 724 − 320 = 404 in our valuation.

• Our items have different values to us so we can “spend” value by giving units that we value less relative to the items the opponent might prize. For example, item 3 is very valuable for us at 90 each, so giving more of item 3 raises the “price” we pay in our own value. To reach 404 exactly we can choose a combination that uses a heavy “cost” item so that the opponent’s bundle appears attractive.
  
• A candidate is to offer Player 2: 1 unit of item1 (11), 1 unit of item2 (17), 4 units of item3 (4×90 = 360), 1 unit of item4 (16), and 0 units of item5. The total “cost” for us is 11+17+360+16+0 = 404, leaving us with a share worth 724 − 404 = 320 raw. Discounting 320 by 0.9 gives 288, which is above our reservation of 283.
  
• In this counteroffer Player 2 receives [1, 1, 4, 1, 0]. It is our hope that giving them 4 units of item3 (a high‐value item in most cases) along with a share of a scarce item (item4) will help swing acceptance.

Thus, I propose the following counteroffer:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 1, 4, 1, 0]}

round_data.response:
I’ll explain my reasoning briefly. I evaluate the current offer, which gives me 2 units of item 1, 11 units of item 2, 1 unit of item 3, 1 unit of item 4, and 3 units of item 5. Using my private per‐unit values (92, 29, 81, 51, 33), my total “raw” value is

  2×92 + 11×29 + 1×81 + 1×51 + 3×33 = 184 + 319 + 81 + 51 + 99 = 734.

Because we are in round 2 the value is discounted by γ^(2-1)=0.9, making my effective payoff about 0.9×734 = 660.6.

My private outside offer guarantees 518, which is considerably lower. Even though a counteroffer might be an option, any further delay (or the risk of ending up with a worse division in round 3) would likely discount the overall value even more. Given that 660.6 well exceeds my outside offer and is a relatively fair outcome for me, it is most beneficial to accept rather than risk renegotiation.

Thus, my action is:

{"action": "ACCEPT"}

round_data.response:
My reasoning:
1. I first looked at my private values: I highly value item3 (59 per unit) and item5 (47 per unit), moderately value item2 (42 per unit), and have relatively low interest in items 1 (11 per unit) and 4 (4 per unit). To maximize my own outcome while still leaving a “good‐enough” offer for the other player, I want to keep my high‐value items (items 3 and 5) as well as most of item2.
2. Since I have no direct information about Player 2’s exact values (they are drawn from a uniform distribution), I want to offer them the items that I value the least. Thus, it makes sense to give them all of item1 (5 units) and all of item4 (8 units).
3. By doing so I keep items 2, 3, and 5 entirely. In my own evaluation that gives me:
  – Item2: all 6 units (6×42 = 252)
  – Item3: all 2 units (2×59 = 118)
  – Item5: the single unit (1×47 = 47)
  for a total of 252+118+47 = 417, which is well above my outside offer of 118.
4. Meanwhile Player 2 receives 5+8 = 13 total units. Although I do not know their exact item values, offering them the items I regard as least valuable to me may be attractive enough relative to their own outside option (even accounting for discounting in later rounds).
5. Given that this is round 1 (no discount yet), it is strategically sound to anchor with a relatively strong offer that maximizes my own share while conceding the items that I do not want.

Thus, my initial offer is to give Player 2 all units of item1 and item4 while keeping the rest for myself.

round_data.response:
{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [4, 0, 1, 2, 1]} 

I explain briefly: The current offer would give me items [4,0,1,2,2] which valuates (raw) to 269 – and when discounted in round 2 (×0.9) only about 242, far below my outside option of 604. In a counteroffer I must secure at least an effective value above 604. Since my total raw value is 929, I need at least roughly 671 raw points (since 671×0.9≈604). By proposing that Player 2 receive [4,0,1,2,1] (i.e. giving up items 1, 3, 4, and one unit of 5) I retain the complement [0,5,4,0,1] which gives me a raw value of 5×80 + 4×65 + 1×44 = 400 + 260 + 44 = 704 (and 704×0.9≈633.6 discounted), which is safely above my outside offer. This counteroffer sacrifices only 225 points (in my private valuation) of the total surplus while offering Player 2 a bundle that, I hope, meets or exceeds their own continuation value.

round_data.response:
I've analyzed our position. Our total value for the full set is 797, and our outside option guarantees 520. Thus any deal we accept must give us at least a value of 520. Our items by unit value are:

• Item 1: 66 (1 unit),
• Item 2: 23 (7 units → 161 total),
• Item 3: 50 (3 units → 150 total),
• Item 4: 15 (4 units → 60 total),
• Item 5: 72 (5 units → 360 total).

A natural idea is to secure the highest‐valued items for ourselves (items 1, 3, and 5) so that we guarantee a total of 66 + 150 + 360 = 576—which is above our 520 reservation. In doing so, we would offer the “lower‐value” (to us) items (items 2 & 4) to the other party. Although we don’t know their private valuations, it is often safe (and standard in negotiations) to give the opponent the items that we value less. Here the offered bundle for Player 2 would be item2: 7 units and item4: 4 units (which in our valuation sums to 161 + 60 = 221). From an average perspective (with values drawn uniformly, average near 51), Player 2 might view these items as having reasonable worth, helping induce acceptance in early rounds where discounting has not yet hurt either party.

Thus, as our initial counteroffer (and since as Player 1 we propose what we “give” to Player 2), our proposal is to give Player 2 all of items 2 and 4 and keep items 1, 3, and 5. This division uses all available items and secures us a value of 576—comfortably above our outside offer of 520.

Our final action is therefore:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 7, 0, 4, 0]}

round_data.response:
My current offer from Player 1 would give me an outcome of only a value of 60 (since I’d receive 0 of item 1, 2 of item 2, and nothing else), which is far below my guaranteed outside option of 596. In order to get a deal that makes it worthwhile to me, I need to insist on receiving items whose total worth (using my private values) is well above 596. At the same time, I must leave enough for Player 1 so that they prefer the deal over their own outside offer—even though their exact numbers are unknown, fairness can often be a good starting point early on.

One natural way to “split the pie” (worth 1290 to me if I got everything) is to aim for something resembling a 50–50 division of the total value. With 5 types of items available in these amounts:
 • Item 1: 5 units
 • Item 2: 4 units
 • Item 3: 5 units
 • Item 4: 5 units
 • Item 5: 4 units

A simple “fair split” would be to give Player 1 about half the units of each item where possible. For instance, if I offer Player 1:
 item 1: 2 units (from 5, I keep 3),
 item 2: 2 units (from 4, I keep 2),
 item 3: 2 units (from 5, I keep 3),
 item 4: 2 units (from 5, I keep 3), and
 item 5: 2 units (from 4, I keep 2).

Then my allocation would be:
 item 1: 3 units → 3 × 96 = 288,
 item 2: 2 units → 2 × 30 = 60,
 item 3: 3 units → 3 × 54 = 162,
 item 4: 3 units → 3 × 56 = 168,
 item 5: 2 units → 2 × 35 = 70.
Summing these gives me a total value of 748, which is well above my outside offer of 596. (This means that even after discounting later rounds—with full value in round 1—this deal is attractive for me.) 

It is likely that offering roughly half the pie is more acceptable to Player 1 than a very skewed division. (Even though I might like to keep more, asking for almost everything would probably make them reject the proposal and opt for their reservation value instead.) 

Thus, my counteroffer is to allocate to Player 1 the following amounts:
[2, 2, 2, 2, 2].

I now provide my action in the required format.

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [2, 2, 2, 2, 2]}

round_data.response:
My goal is to secure most of the high‐value items for myself while giving Player 2 just enough so that their share is above what they might expect from their outside option or from waiting for later rounds (especially given the discounting). In my evaluation my values for the items are very different from the average expected values for Player 2; for instance, I value item 2 relatively low (38 per unit) while on average Player 2 might see about 51 per unit. Thus, by conceding full control of item 2 I "buy" Player 2’s agreement with relatively low cost to me while keeping all of the more valuable items for myself. I have also considered that offering even a small portion of item 1 (valued only 11 by me) can further bridge any gap so that Player 2’s payoff is acceptable (since even 1 unit of item 1 would add roughly 51 expected points for them). 

Based on these considerations, my initial proposal is to offer Player 2 all of item 2 (4 units) and 1 unit of item 1, while keeping all of the remaining items. This offer (i.e. giving Player 2 the allocation [1, 4, 0, 0, 0]) results in me keeping:
• Item 1: 5 units (worth 55 for me),
• Item 2: 0 units,
• Item 3: 7 units (worth 385),
• Item 4: 6 units (worth 432),
• Item 5: 1 unit (worth 91),
totaling a value of 55 + 385 + 432 + 91 = 1063.
Player 2’s expected “lot” (using rough average estimates for their unknown private values) should be competitive relative to their outside offer. 

Thus, my move in round 1 is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 4, 0, 0, 0]}

round_data.response:
Step 1: Calculate our payoff if we accept the current offer.
• We receive 7 units of item 2 and 7 units of item 5.
• Our per-unit values: item 2 = 23, item 5 = 12.
• Value from item 2 = 7 × 23 = 161.
• Value from item 5 = 7 × 12 = 84.
• Total value = 161 + 84 = 245.

Step 2: Compare with our outside offer.
• Our outside offer is 108.
• The value of 245 from accepting is much higher.

Step 3: Consider strategic factors.
• Negotiating further could incur a discount (gamma = 0.9) in later rounds.
• The current offer gives us full round-1 value without discount.
• It is not beneficial to prolong negotiations when the current offer exceeds our outside offer by a significant margin.

Step 4: Conclusion.
• Accepting the current offer provides a strong, immediate value compared to both our outside offer and the uncertain prospects of further negotiations.

Final decision:
{"action": "ACCEPT"}

round_data.response:
I want to break down my reasoning briefly.

My total “basket‐value” (using my private per‐unit values) if I took all items would be 
  4×58 + 0×17 + 7×38 + 5×50 + 5×14 = 818.
My outside (disagreement) option guarantees 616.
Player 1’s current offer gives me [0, 0, 7, 0, 1] which is worth 
  0×58 + 0×17 + 7×38 + 0×50 + 1×14 = 266 + 14 = 280,
far below my fallback.

Thus I need to negotiate for a share that gives me at least 616 (undiscounted in round 1). In a counteroffer I state what I would “give” to Player 1; whatever is not given goes to me. If I let my allocation be “a” and the offered vector (for Player 1) be “c”, then
  a = available – c,
and my value is 818 – (58·(c₁) + 38·(c₃) + 50·(c₄) + 14·(c₅)). 
To guarantee at least 616 for me we need:
  818 – (58c₁ + 38c₃ + 50c₄ + 14c₅) ≥ 616 
⟹ 58c₁ + 38c₃ + 50c₄ + 14c₅ ≤ 202.

A natural “boundary” offer is to leave me exactly with 616 so that I’m not conceding more than necessary.
One possible feasible division is to let Player 1 have:
  1 unit of item 1 (cost 58),
  1 unit of item 3 (cost 38),
  1 unit of item 4 (cost 50),
  4 units of item 5 (cost 4×14 = 56).
Total “cost” = 58 + 38 + 50 + 56 = 202.

Then my allocation becomes:
  Item 1: 4 − 1 = 3 units (3×58 = 174)
  Item 2: 0 − 0 = 0
  Item 3: 7 − 1 = 6 units (6×38 = 228)
  Item 4: 5 − 1 = 4 units (4×50 = 200)
  Item 5: 5 − 4 = 1 unit (1×14 = 14)
for a total of 174 + 228 + 200 + 14 = 616.

Since 616 is exactly my fallback (and any accepted deal is multiplied by gamma^(r–1) = 1 in round 1), this counteroffer leaves me indifferent between accepting the deal and my outside option. It also gives Player 1 a “package” that might beat his own outside offer. (Of course, we don’t know his precise values but offering him items in this way is a reasonable starting point in our negotiation.)

Thus, I will respond with the counteroffer:
  {"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 0, 1, 1, 4]}

round_data.response:
I first calculated the value of the current offer to me. Receiving [1, 5, 0, 0, 0] means I get:
• 1 of item 1 × 9 = 9 
• 5 of item 2 × 74 = 370 
• 0 of item 3, 4, and 5 = 0 
Total = 379.

Since no discount applies in round 1 (γ^(0)=1), I realize that accepting this offer gives me a value of 379—far above my outside option of 22. Although there might be room to negotiate for a better share (for example, gaining some of the high‐value item 5), delaying or countering risks prolonging negotiation into rounds where discounting (γ = 0.9) would reduce the final value. In addition, without knowing Player 1’s private values, trying to push for a re‐allocation may jeopardize closing a deal that already provides me with a very strong outcome.

Given these factors, I conclude that the best action is to accept the current offer.

{"action": "ACCEPT"}

round_data.response:
I’ll explain my thinking briefly. I want to achieve a deal that’s better for me than my outside option of 607 while offering enough to Player 2 so that, based on an (unknown but roughly average) unit value of about 51 per unit, they would see a similar “fair‐share” prospect. My own values are very high for items 1 and 4 and moderately high for item 5, so I want to keep items that score high for me while offloading items that I value less (items 2 and 3) as well as part of item 5. In total there are 19 units. An even “fair” split in expected value for Player 2 would be roughly 9–10 units (about 9.5 units in expectation, given an average near 51 per unit). I can promise them all of item 2 (4 units) plus the only unit of item 3 (1 unit) and then add 5 units from item 5; that gives Player 2 10 total units (roughly 510 expected value) while leaving for me:
 • Item 1: 2 units
 • Item 4: all 5 units
 • Item 5: the remaining 2 units (7 – 5)
Thus my own bundle is worth a lot to me (2×93 + 5×87 + 2×63 = 747) and exceeds my outside option. This split uses the items I value less to “buy” agreement with Player 2. So my initial proposal is to offer Player 2 the items [0, 4, 1, 0, 5] (meaning 0 of item 1, 4 of item 2, 1 of item 3, 0 of item 4, and 5 of item 5).

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 4, 1, 0, 5]}

Step‐by‐step reasoning:
1. Our total available items are: 4 units of item 1, 4 of item 2, 1 of item 3, 5 of item 4, and 4 of item 5. My private values are very high for items 1 (90), 3 (53) and 4 (59), and relatively low for items 2 (4) and 5 (18). In many negotiation puzzles, it is typical that what is highly valued by one party tends to be less valuable for the other. Thus, we can suspect that Player 2 will likely value items 2 and 5 more highly.
2. My strategic aim is to secure the items that matter most to me while offering Player 2 the items that I care less about but likely have high value for them. By keeping almost all of item 1, 3, and 4 for myself and offering all of items 2 and 5 to Player 2, I maximize my own total value.
3. In numbers:
 • I keep: 4 units of item 1, 1 unit of item 3, and 5 units of item 4. My value from these becomes 4×90 + 1×53 + 5×59 = 360 + 53 + 295 = 708.
 • I give to Player 2: 4 units of item 2 and 4 units of item 5.
4. This division gives Player 2 all of the items that I personally value rather little, while awarding me almost everything that counts for my utility. Given that our negotiation is in round 1 (with no discount yet) and noting that my outside offer is very low (57), this initial counteroffer is designed to be attractive to Player 2 as well—assuming that their high interest lies in items 2 and 5.
5. Therefore, my initial offer (as Player 1) is to propose that Player 2 receives [0, 4, 0, 0, 4] (i.e. nothing of items 1, 3, and 4, and full allocation for items 2 and 5), with me obtaining the remainder.

Final action:

round_data.response:
Step 1. My total value if I keep everything is 679. My private outside option is 602, so I must secure at least 602 in my own “bundle‐value” in any deal I accept. In other words, I can only concede at most 679 – 602 = 77 points from my full value in this negotiation.

Step 2. My per‐unit values are:
 • Item 1: 48
 • Item 2: 36
 • Item 3: 3
 • Item 4: 77
 • Item 5: 17

I want to concede items that cost me little first. Item 3, with a cost of 3 per unit, is very “cheap” for me. Item 5 is next (17 per unit) and then item 2 (36 per unit). Items 1 and 4 are very valuable to me so I want to keep those.

Step 3. I assign integer concessions (i.e. give whole units to Player 2) so that the reduction in my total value is as close as possible to 77 while not dropping me below my outside offer.

A useful combination found is:
 • Concede 2 units of Item 3: cost 2×3 = 6 
 • Concede 2 units of Item 5: cost 2×17 = 34 
 • Concede 1 unit of Item 2: cost 1×36 = 36 
Total cost = 6 + 34 + 36 = 76.

Step 4. My resulting allocated bundle is then:
 • Item 1: I keep all 6 units (offer 0).
 • Item 2: I keep 3 – 1 = 2 units.
 • Item 3: I keep 6 – 2 = 4 units.
 • Item 4: I keep all 3 units (offer 0).
 • Item 5: I keep 2 – 2 = 0 units.

My final value = 6×48 + 2×36 + 4×3 + 3×77 + 0×17 = 288 + 72 + 12 + 231 + 0 = 603, which is just above my outside offer of 602.

Step 5. In the negotiation protocol our offer is represented as a list of numbers indicating how many units of each item I give to Player 2. Therefore, my counteroffer is:
 Offer to Player 2 = [0 (Item 1), 1 (Item 2), 2 (Item 3), 0 (Item 4), 2 (Item 5)].

I now present my action in the required format.

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 1, 2, 0, 2]}

round_data.response:
My analysis is as follows. My full value (if I got every unit) is 1142, but my outside offer guarantees 1120. That leaves a surplus of only 22 points available from any negotiated division. In order for a deal to beat my outside offer, I must secure an outcome that gives me at least 1120. Since I get my value from the items I keep (the ones not given to Player 2), any unit I “give away” loses me its unit value. My values for items 1–5 are 57, 73, 92, 18, and 60 respectively. The only unit that costs me relatively little is one unit of item 4 (worth 18); even that is nearly all of my available surplus (22–18 = 4 left). And no other item’s unit can be afforded (the next least value is 57, which overshoots my slack).

This means the only “concession” I could safely offer (while being assured of a deal better than my outside offer) would be something like giving Player 2 one unit of item 4, leaving me with a total value of 1142 – 18 = 1124. However, from Player 2’s perspective—given that their private values are drawn uniformly between 1 and 101 and that their outside offer is drawn from a range up to their overall total value—it is very likely that receiving just one unit of item 4 (which I estimate would be worth around 51 on average to them) is far below what they might expect from their own outside offer. In short, the surplus available in this negotiation is so tiny that any concession designed to induce Player 2 to accept would require giving up too much for me.

Given that even a “generous” (for Player 2) offer would force me to lose too much value relative to my outside option, it is most rational for me to simply avoid a negotiated deal and take my outside offer of 1120, rather than risk further discounting in later rounds. 

Thus, my decision is to WALK.

{"action": "WALK"}

round_data.response:
My reasoning:
• I want to secure items that have high value to me (especially item 3 and item 1) while leaving the other items in a way that offers Player 2 an attractive option relative to their unknown values and outside offer.
• My total value if I got everything would be 1237, and my outside offer gives 414 (with no discount in round 1). I must beat that, while offering Player 2 an expected benefit (based on unknown values) that is likely attractive compared to what they might expect.
• A nearly balanced split in terms of item quantities might be too even for my advantage. Instead, I try to retain more of the high‐value items. In my counteroffer [1, 3, 2, 2, 1], I give Player 2:
  – 1 unit of item 1,
  – 3 units of item 2,
  – 2 units of item 3,
  – 2 units of item 4,
  – 1 unit of item 5;
 which leaves me with the remaining units [3, 3, 4, 2, 2]. This allocation gives me a higher total value based on my private valuations while still offering Player 2 a set of items that (with their unknown values) should be compelling.
• This offer is designed to be favorable for me in terms of value (790 by my estimates) while giving Player 2 a reasonable share to increase the chance of acceptance in round 1.

Thus, my action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 3, 2, 2, 1]}

• Item 1: 1 unit × 5 = 5

My outside offer is only 114 so even a modest deal is far better. Although I might try to raise my share on the items I value highly (especially item 4), any counteroffer risks delay—which would discount the payoff (with a factor of 0.9 per subsequent round) and introduce uncertainty about Player 1’s reaction given I have no insight into their private values. With 303 compared to my reservation value and with no delay discount in round 1, the current offer is attractive and safe.

Thus, my best action is to ACCEPT the current offer.

{"action": "ACCEPT"}
